text:
Thank you so much
for inviting me here

to be a part of this
important gathering.

I was a student at
the Divinity School
on the other side of campus.

They kept us over
there for a reason.

I was never allowed here on
this campus for some reason.

I don't think prayer and
capitalism really mix together.
But it's so nice here.
[LAUGHTER]

To begin with, my name
is Lama Rod Owens.
I use he/him pronouns.

And I live and teach on and
am from the ancestral lands

of the Creek, Cherokee,
and Muscogee people,

on the land that we call
Atlanta in Georgia now.

And I bring you
greetings and blessings

from the spirit of that land
and the ancestors and guardians

of that land to this
land, the ancestral

lands of the Wampanoag,
Massachusetts,

Nipmuc people, and many
other tribes and communities.

I also bring you blessings
from my ancestors, who

support me and walk with
me in everything that I do.

Whose love as well as rage
created the conditions for me

to be here to not only
survive, but to thrive

in this body and this land,
and to commit and further

engage in the work
of liberation,

which is my primary project
in life, is to get free,
to get free through love.

I wrote a book called Love
and Rage, where I explored

the relationships
between love and rage,

much like this
conference, which I think

is called Rage and Love,
maybe for copyright reasons.
I don't know.
Maybe?
[LAUGHTER]

Maybe it was fear
that I would somehow
assimilate this into my resume.

But it's close enough that it
already has been assimilated.

And I wrote that book
because this thing

happened a couple of years ago
that I think a couple of people
noticed.
There was this election.
This guy got elected.
I don't want to go into it.
It's really painful.
But a lot of people were pissed.
Some of you were pissed.

And people kept coming
to me and asking me,
what are we going to do?
I'm so pissed off.

And I would say, why
are you asking me?
I don't want to talk about this.

But over time, the
questions kept coming,

and I saw that as a sign for me
to actually explore something

that I think most people
didn't really know

were in a relationship,
which was love and rage.

But a lot of people talking
about love and a lot of people

talking about freedom,
which is where
we go in between love and rage.

I think when people
talk about these words,

I think people are talking
about very different things.

And so just to begin with,
when I talk about love,
I'm not talking about a feeling.

Like, I'm not talking about a
feeling of caring for someone.

I'm talking about a
fundamental belief

that everyone deserves a
right to be happy, safe,

and to have access
to all the resources
that they need to be well.
Period.
And I don't care who you are.

And I don't have to
like you to love you.

And that's where some
of you are getting
confused at with this work.

Like, I don't have
to like you for me

to want you to be safe
and happy and resourced.

If I don't like
you, it just means
I'm not going to be your BFF.

We're not going to be texting,
sending TikTok videos back
and forth to one another.

We're not going to go out
hanging out at the bar.

We're not going to
be doing any of that.

But I am committing to not to
getting in the way of what you

need to be safe, because maybe
some of the violence that I

perceive coming from
you comes from the fact

that you're
underresourced, or maybe

you never got the
resources you needed
to begin with in your life.

And so I want to
be an agent that

helps you to be
resourced because I'm

interested in the reduction of
violence and harm in the world.

And it doesn't mean that I'm not
interested in accountability.

It doesn't mean I'm not
interested in boundaries,

because boundaries and
accountability come from love.

They're not acts of
punishment or retribution.

I don't engage in
these practices

because I want you to hurt
as much as I've been hurt.
I want you to be free.

And that's the
primary ethic that I

think we have to return
to, is that everyone

needs to be free from
this, including ourselves.
That's where love comes from.
Again, I don't have to like you.

There are a lot of
people I don't like.
But I try to love everyone.
So when I talk about freedom--

and I am informed
through my tradition

of contemplative practice, which
is meditation and mindfulness,

as well as the spiritual
paths that I've trained in,

which have been a few,
but primarily Buddhism

has been one of my
primary spiritual paths.

So when I talk about freedom,
I'm talking about two things.
First, social freedom.

Again, that we're free from
the causes and conditions that

create harm and suffering for
individuals and communities,

that everyone has
access to the resources

that they need to
be well, that we

get to determine the
course of our bodies

and we get to determine the
course of our communities

as long as these decisions
do not create further harm
and violence.

And that is a discussion that
has to be had in community.

When do my actions create harm
for others, and what is harm?

I mention this
because we're confused

about being unsafe and
being uncomfortable.
And it's conflated.

And I think that's giving rise
to a lot of violence right now.

I think a lot of people are just
uncomfortable because they've

been allowed to take
up a lot of space.

And now we're calling
that space out

as something that needs to
be disrupted and reduced.

And then people are seeing that
as an act of harm against them.

And then if you feel
unsafe, then you're

going to react that
experience of being unsafe

probably through violence,
protecting yourself, protecting
your loved ones and so forth.

So that's like the
first kind of freedom.

But ultimate freedom for
me, from my traditions,

means that I transcend
dualities and binaries.

I return to this basic,
fundamental expression

of what some may call
God, but in my experience

and my practice, I say
I am returning back

to this fundamental
expression of emptiness,

space, fluidity, which for me
is also an expression of love.
I am remembering who I am.

And so mainstream
mindfulness, for instance,

comes from a tradition in
Buddhism called the four
foundations of mindfulness.

The root name is
the Satipatthana.

So from the Satipatthana
to mainstream mindfulness,

we've missed something
really important,

which is the value and
the ethic of freedom.

Mainstream mindfulness is
about assimilation, comfort,

but the root of
Buddhist-based mindfulness
is about getting free.
It's about reducing violence.

It's about deeply
embodying love,

which will actually
disrupt and abolish
systems that perpetuate harm.

So why would we
teach a mainstream

mindfulness that's actually
about disrupting the systems

that many people benefit
from, including all of us
in this room, quite honestly?

So the root of the
Satipatthana is not just

meditating to get free, but
the root of the Satipatthana
is remembering.

The Satipatthana
means to remember,
to remember who you are.

So we are not the
chaos, but that's

what we begin to self-identify
with, with the violence,

with the systems, like
patriarchy, white supremacy,
ableism and so forth.

We think that's who we are,
but in the root practice

of the Satipatthana,
we begin to divest

from those self-identifications
with systems of harm

and to reinvest in
who we really are,

which is an embodiment
and an expression of love.

And that love is an expression
of space, fluidity, potential.

But to give up, to start
divesting from these systems

and to start reinvesting
in who we are

means that we have to deal
with the broken-heartedness,

the deep mourning and grief
that has to be acknowledged

because we are
giving up something
that we thought we were.

And that's the
struggle right now.
This is a moment of apocalypse.

An apocalypse doesn't
mean the end of anything.
That's a misunderstanding.
You're talking about Armageddon.
I'm not dealing with Armageddon.
I don't have training in that.
But I do have training--

I don't have that
degree from here,

but I am really familiar
with apocalypse.
Apocalypse means truth telling.
It means unveiling.

But when someone tells you
the truth about something

you don't want to
deal with, it's

going to feel violent because
you don't want to deal with it.

And because you don't
want to deal with it,

you're going to weaponize
yourself and begin to create
harm and protect yourself.

So you're doing that,
but so is the collective.

So that makes it harder
for us to be in the world

right now, because the
systems that we no longer need

are actually being disrupted
and moving towards abolishment.
And that feels like dying.

When you self-identify
with something,

when that thing begins
to be disrupted,

it feels like you
are being disrupted.

In many ways, we can talk about
white supremacy in this case,

where some of you are
so self-identified--
I was going to say all of you--

some of us are so
self-identified

with white supremacy that to
disrupt white supremacy feels
like an actual death.

And most people
aren't willing to die.
And that is the dilemma.

The same with patriarchy,
a deep investment

in the system of
hierarchy and privilege.

To disrupt patriarchy,
and if you're

self-identified with the
system of patriarchy,

then it's going to
feel like death.

And of course, in
patriarchy, when

privileges are given to certain
people, cisgender men, who

already have this power,
then that weaponizing

of this feeling of harm is going
to create a lot of destruction
and a lot of harm.

So in this case, are
you willing to die

to get free is really
the point of this.

Not a physical death, but the
death of who you think you are.

This is, I think,
the root of my work.

And I'm going to get
to rage in a second,
but this is the point here.

We all do good work and we all
talk a good game and many of us

get paid really well, looking
at the institutions that
are represented here.
Hallelujah.

But what are you
actually willing

to do to transition this
world, to transition

your communities into this
experience of freedom?

What are you still
holding on to?

And some of us
say, why do I have
to be the one to sacrifice?
Well, why not?
Why not me?
It's a hard price.

But again, a lot of folks
who are talking about freedom

aren't really talking
about getting free.

You're talking about getting
comfortable and getting happy.

You're talking about
reforming institutions

so you can maintain some level
of comfort and privilege.

Like, why should you
have to be uncomfortable?

That's not really the practice
of my ancestors and the people

that I study, particularly
the anti-slave abolitionists,

where I root my work and
spiritual abolition in.

I think about Harriet Tubman,
for instance, who was like,
listen, you get two choices--
get free or not.

And you need to die trying to
get free if you're not free.

How do we bring that ethic
back into our own work
and say what am I willing to do.
What am I willing to sacrifice?

How am I willing to
let my heart break

and, in letting my heart
break, allow myself

to be held by all the
beings around me who love me

so I can begin to transition
into an understanding of myself

that is essentially free,
fluid, full of potential,

divine, sacred, instead of
always choosing this material

form that's so self-identified
with the sense of ego that's

attached to power and hierarchy
and comfort and validation
and being seen.
So I'm going to get into anger.

And for me, anger is the
bodyguard of our hurts.

When people say I'm angry,
what I hear them saying

is that they've been
hurt and they're

trying to figure out how
to take care of themselves.
Anger is a secondary emotion.

And I think that's
where we stop at.

We think anger is the main
show, but in fact anger
is pointing us back to the hurt.

Many of us will
never get to the hurt

because the energy of
anger is so intense.
And we overvalue anger.

We think anger has much more
value and data than we realize.

And I know that Audre talked
about the data of anger.
Anger is full of data and power.

And it is, but it's not
how we get things done.
It's energy.

But we get things done because
we began to name the hurt.

And the hurt calls in the
experience of deep loving.

And it's from this experience
of love, the love that's

holding my hurt, that
I begin to engage

with the world in a way that's
transformational and generative

instead of in a way
that feels destructive
and out of control and reactive.

When I put anger and
love together and rage

and love together, what
I was actually saying

is that it is my love that
holds the experience of anger.

Love cares for everything,
including my deep hurt.

If we forget all of that, then
we get lost in this tension.

So we get hurt and
the anger arises,

and we're trying to figure out
how to take care of ourselves,
and we don't know how to.

So there's a tension
between being hurt

and the anger that
we get wrapped up in.

And then that's when we
start reacting to things

and practicing anger,
practicing rage.

And again, I am not
angry, I am not hurt.
These are experiences, really.

And this is where we can
begin to experience liberation

in our minds and our
bodies, when we understand
that these are experiences.
This isn't who I am.
I am not angry.

If I am angry, then how can I
actually transcend something
that I am?

These are experiences because
you're not always angry.

And that's actually not
the nature of who you are.

But it's something that is
happening for many of us

in the moment, as
well as the hurt.

But there are many
things that are

happening in the moment,
including our joy.

So anger sometimes means
that we forget our joy.

But we have to reconnect to
the joy in the same way we

reconnect to the
love, because these

are energies that hold the
destructive power that anger
can become.

And then if we are
holding these experiences,

then we have the agency
to channel these energies

into creating, into
supporting, into healing,

into re-establishing,
into peace.

Not just into
reactivity, thinking

that we're going to
weaponize all of this

to get back at
everyone who's hurt us.

And this is going to
require a personal change

and individual change that
many people aren't ready for.

I think sometimes we
overemphasize collective change

because we don't want to
deal with the individual work
that we need to do.

But we'll never move
forward until some of us

start actually investing
in an interpersonal change

in our lives, and
to bring that work
into collective relationships.

So this is like the relationship
between love and rage for me.

I am someone who
experiences a lot of anger.

I am someone who
experiences a lot of hurt.

But I am being held
by love, and that love

is a deep joy that
keeps me moving

in the world, that keeps
me dancing and singing
and laughing.

The world is in a lot
of transition and pain,

but I don't have to get
swallowed by that pain.
I can hold that.

I can hold the transition
of my communities.

I can hold interpersonal
and transhistorical traumas
that have been passed to me.

But I have to be
willing to commit

to love, commit
to the heartbreak,

and commit to the mourning, and
to open to the love and joy.

And the anger is there, and we
can tune in and out of anger

as a source of energy,
but that energy
is informed and held by love.

And if you can do
that, then you will

begin to see a different
kind of change in the world.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
